https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/68041/ : SUCCESS
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 052bcbf48802da1fa9583c8c0990378304e29903
Like we talked about, please keep support for the old URI.  They can call similar methods, but we can't day zero drop support for an API that has existed for as many years as this one has.

The backward compatibility will be maintained by webui. Following drop handles that and must be merged before mine.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/63442

> The backward compatibility will be maintained by webui

No thank you.  Please maintain api compatibility at the API boundary.  Changing one client does not maintain compatibility for anything but that client.
ok, In that case we need to register one more router. One for /console0 and second for /console/<str>. Is that what you are envisioning?
Yes, that would be what I'm envisioning.
Done
Why does a pre-built list of elements prevent service attacks?

We can not completely avoid it but we are trying to avoid DBUS call for bad string attach. This is from the discussion on my earlier drop. 

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/62525?tab=comments
I will remove the console list for now.
Done
Please help to review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/63851
This should not be a global variable.  It's essentially storing mapper state, which should remain in the mapper.
No, we should not store state at all.
Are you suggesting to completely remove list and keep what we had before?
Completely remove the list.
Done
Why are we calling the mapper here again?  Can we just call obmc console directly?  Even if we're calling the mapper, we should be calling GetObject
This is to build the list of consoles. We need to get the list of paths. This is called once at the start of bmcweb.

> This is to build the list of consoles.

WHY?  This is counter to DBUS_USAGE.md.  If you want to get a console in a daemon-independent manner, use the mapper (GetObject).  In this case, I suspect we can just call the daemon directly until we have another user.
ok, I will remove the console list for now.
Done
Please use sdbusplus::object_path::operator/ to construct this.  That is called out in COMMON_ERRORS.md

It is not clear which method is correct. There is no example given in the COMMON_ERROR.md. I have followed steps from https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/6f8273e49cffdd347c223b9538558edfb05e818a/redfish-core/lib/certificate_service.hpp#L1070

Ah, this might be the confusion.  Every console is being implemented by its own dbus connection?

In which case the right way would be to use GetObject on the mapper to look up the service.
yes, Each console has its own DBUS object. For now I am directly making connect call which fails if console path is not valid.
Then please use the mapper.

You're taking a URI and parsing it as a dbus path.  Even if it compiles, it's not correct.

I suspect what you want is 

std::string_view leaf = *conn.req.uri.segments().last();
sdbusplus::message::object_path("/xyz/openbmc_project/console") / leaf
I tried this but I am getting compilation errors. It doesn't find uri. Can you please share the document?
What code did you try?  What document are you looking for?

I tried this and it gave compilation error. I am looking for document which provides boost http request where uri is defined.

std::string_view leaf = *conn.req.uri.segments().last();

Request is this type so I need some document in the boost.

boost::beast::http::request<boost::beast::http::string_body> req;

This is a compilation error I got.

| ../../../../../../../../../bmcweb/include/obmc_console.hpp:211:41: error: 'boost::beast::http::request<boost::beast::http::basic_string_body<char> >' {aka 'class boost::beast::http::message<true, boost::beast::http::basic_string_body<char>, boost::beast::http::basic_fields<std::allocator<char> > >'} has no member named 'uri'
|   211 |     std::string consoleLeaf = *conn.req.uri.segments().last();
|       |                                         ^~~
take a look at what I just posted to your commit.  I believe I fixed it.  Please help to test.
ok, Thanks. Testing....
Done
If we're going to multiple service names, this should be using the mapper.  GetObject call.

The object path name and service name will be always prefixed with "/xyz/openbmc_project/console/<console_id>" and "xyz.openbmc_project.Console.<console_id>" hence Jonathan suggested not to query DBUS in his last drop.
Please use the typesafe uri object, not target().  This will fail if there are things like fragments or query params in the uri.
I couldn't find the uri object in the request. when I tried with *conn.req.uri.segments(). I got the compilation errors. I found this document which talks about target() method but nothing about uri.
Can this branch be done earlier, and just set consoleLeaf to "default" so we're not duplicating all the construction?
Done
please just put this in the above method.  no need for a new one.
yes, I tested the fix and it is working fine. Thanks a lot.
Sorry I closed this by mistake.
Done
This needs to be using the mapper.  GetObject call.

As written, this is a security issue, otherwise I normally wouldn't care

You could in theory access

/console/0$*%^*#%  and it would kick bmcweb off dbus.

I tried this string but it did not even reached the router. I can still work on the getDbusObject() call.

  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/websockets/legacy/client.py", line 482, in __init__
    wsuri = parse_uri(uri)
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/websockets/uri.py", line 81, in parse_uri
    raise exceptions.InvalidURI(uri, "fragment identifier is meaningless")
websockets.exceptions.InvalidURI: wss://rain136bmc:443/console/0$%^#% isn't a valid URI: fragment identifier is meaningless

you didn't escape your string characters in your request, so python is complaining.  If you are interested in learning how URI escaping works, hope on discord and I can help you, but I promise you this is something we need to handle.

Keep in mind that for dbus connection names, there are naming rules that you're not allowed to break.

I have forced the string in the code and DBUS just returned invalid argument. When you say it would kick off dbus what do you mean?

 [DEBUG "obmc_console.hpp":247] Console Object path = /xyz/openbmc_project/console/_30_24_25_5e_23_25_25 service = xyz.openbmc_project.Console.0$%^#%% Request target = /console0
 [ERROR "obmc_console.hpp":178] Failed to call console Connect() method DBUS error: Invalid argument
I am not trying to avoid the work but just trying to understand the security issue. Looks like this is just going to have some failure. I thought it might core dump but it did not.

> Failed to call console Connect() method DBUS error: Invalid argument

This was a thrown exception that didn't get handled (at least it used to be).

> I am not trying to avoid the work but just trying to understand the security issue.

I appreciate you.  I wasn't saying you were avoiding work.  If that was how it sounded, i apologize.
ok, thanks. So now that its not dumping core, do you still think I should add getDbusObject() call?
Yes.

I should answer this more thoroughly.  I want this code relying on the same code that everything else is.  In your case, you actually kind of rebuilt the mapper in that global variable originally, so it's roughly what you were thinking, we just call out to an external provider.
ok, Thanks. I will handle it.
Done

A couple minor things, looks good to me.

Leaving time for others to review.

'req.url()' is a part of 'req', and thus it can also be obtained inside websocket.
Then, this part would not need to be changed.

req is going away in the next patchset, which is why this pipes through URI.

fine as-is.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61219/6?usp=related-change
Marking resolved based on Ed's comment.
This `urlViewIn` is `reqIn.url()` from `routing.hpp`, and then, this can be removed
See above comment.  req is going away.
Marking resolved based on Ed's comment.

As  uurlViewIn is reqIn.url() from routing.hpp, this can be written as
```
uri(reqIn.url()), 
```
reqIn is going away.
Marking resolved based on Ed's comment.
req is going away.
Marking resolved based on Ed's comment.
This is the check you want to use on any callback.
Done
Done

this was acquired through an unsafe capture.

Please do a getConsoleHandlerMap().find() before using this object.
Done
Done
@Myung I'm still happy to continue this conversation if you believe something is wrong here, but it looks correct to me.
